awd_titl_txt: Targeted Interventions for Enhanced Retention of Chemistry Graduate Students
awd_abstract_narration:
This NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) project will increase the number of students who complete a Ph.D. in chemistry and contribute to the vital national chemistry enterprise.  The project has four objectives (a) increase the retention rate of graduate students who most commonly encounter barriers in their first year, (b) use carefully targeted interventions to reduce the average time-to-degreee, (c) increase the number of graduate students in the department from groups that are underrepresented in Chemistry, and (d) improve the overall graduate experience by adding coherence and breadth to skills development, reducing teaching workloads, and supporting students seeking non-research careers upon Ph.D. completion. The immediate outcome of the project will be the awarding scholarships to at least 52 graduate students. The long-term outcome will be more, better prepared, advance-degreed professionals for the workforce.

The project goals are aligned with challenges to the chemistry graduate program that were identified in a self-assessment.  Thus, the three new student support mechanisms (Professional Develop Workshops, Proposal Writing Course, and Near Peer Mentoring) were chosen carefully to focus on key attrition points, all predominant in the first year of study.  The topics covered in the workshops will help the students to develop their identities as professional scientist, while the writing course will help them to develop their abilities to design a viable research plan.  Grounded in the literature, these strategies will both provide the S-STEM students with strong academic support and further inform the research on recruitment and retention of graduate students in the sciences.  Moreover, all of the project components are examples of sustainable, transferrable tools for training graduate students.  The Evaluation Plan includes validated, baseline and follow-up surveys meant to assess the development of participants' self-efficacy (research and academic) and STEM Identities.  The individual support structures will also be evaluated using qualitative, focus group discussions.  Both mechanisms should result in rich information regarding the attitudes, motivation, and beliefs of budding graduate students.  The qualitative assessments, which will be expanded to a group of students who have not been exposed to the student supports for comparison, should build on current research related to challenges to persistence in graduate school.  Results will be disseminated to the university, national chemistry, and broader STEM communities through a variety of mechanisms including PittCon meetings, annual American Chemical Society meetings, and the Journal of Chemical Education.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the Targeted Interventions for Enhanced Retention of Chemistry Graduate Students project is to provide financial support to enable more students to have a successful graduate experience and who upon degree completion, will contribute to the vital national chemical enterprise, aligning with the missions of the S-STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) program and the Department of Chemistry at the University of Pittsburgh.

We acknowledge and greatly appreciate support from the Dietrich School of Arts and Sciences, the Department of Chemistry, Chemistry's Chief Administrative Officer, Chemistry's Graduate Administrative Assistant, Chemistry faculty mentors, and the faculty developers of the proposal writing course. Through their support we completed a successful project, including working through changes in the research enterprise caused by COVID — initiated in March 2020 and continuing through 2021.

Outcome 1: This alternative term of funding, the S-STEM scholarship (i.e., not a Teaching Fellow appointment, nor a Graduate Student Research appointment) allowed the fellow to focus solely on the required aspects of their chemistry research program of study, including conducting experiments, analyzing data, and/or writing (e.g., comprehensive exam, thesis, proposal, dissertation) for one full term (4 months) of an academic year. The 'stress relief' for all parties (both fellow and mentor) allowed significant progress to be made towards the targeted degree (to date, 32 PhDs (dissertations), 5 Masters (theses), and 10 Fellows still pursuing the PhD). Timely receipt of one-term of fellowship support for graduate students at key transition points in their pursuit of an advanced degree proved to be beneficial to mentor and fellow based upon a significant increase in graduate student retention rate (78% for Fellows vs 54% historical/pre-award data).

Outcome 2:  With support from the University for tuition remission and health care expenses, the project dedicated more than 93% of the funding to direct student scholarships in the form of 64 one-term [4-month] awards to 54 unique Fellows distributed among 29 different faculty mentors, all within the Department of Chemistry. The majority of awards (75%) were at the $10,000 level with the other 25% ranged from $2855 to $9125 per award.

Outcome 3:  Analysis of the distributed awards establishes that the summer term is a key transition point for many graduate students as 73% of the one-term scholarships were for the summer term (14% for fall and 13% for spring terms).

Outcome 4: The S-STEM proposal-turned-to-grant led to the creation of a novel 1-credit graduate course on proposal writing aimed at explicit improvements in graduate writing via a structured experience, and at improved graduate fellowship proposal preparation for national and institutional opportunities. This course offered in the first years of the grant led to an increase in submission of NSF GRFPs and awarding of predoctoral fellows and the departmental course being supplanted with a university workshop/course for proposal development for graduate students.
